extendedIngredients.name: crème fraîche
extendedIngredients.original: 1 cup creme fraiche or sour cream

extendedIngredients.name: shrimp
extendedIngredients.original: 1 pound large shrimp, shelled and deveined, leaving tails on
extendedIngredients.originalName: shrimp, shelled and deveined, leaving tails on

title: Shrimp with Green Goddess Sauce
summary: Shrimp with Green Goddess Sauce is a gluten free, primal, and pescatarian recipe with 4 servings. One serving contains 232 calories, 25g of protein, and 13g of fat. For $3.51 per serving, this recipe covers 15% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. It works best as a main course, and is done in approximately 9 minutes. If you have freshly cracked pepper, lemon zest, kosher salt, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the kosher salt you could follow this main course with the Low Fat Crumbs Cake (Kosher-Dairy) as a dessert. 4 people have made this recipe and would make it again. It is brought to you by Foodnetwork. With a spoonacular score of 57%, this dish is solid. Similar recipes include Shrimp with Green Goddess Sauce, Crudités And Shrimp With Green Goddess Dip, and Roasted Shrimp Cocktail with Green Goddess Dressing.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Riesling, and Sauvignon Blanc are my top picks for Shrimp. These crisp white wines work well with shrimp prepared in a variety of ways, whether grilled, fried, or in garlic sauce. The Jean Biecher Pinot Gris with a 5 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 18 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Jean Biecher Pinot Gris
productMatches.description:
This Pinot Gris has a beautiful yellow-gold color. Rich in aromatic complexity, Pinot Gris can reveal typically smoky notes as well as delicious aromas of dried fruit, apricot, honey, beeswax and gingerbread. This ample and fleshy wine is sustained by a delightful tension which gives the wine a full-bodied structure. The finish is long and well balanced.ave a noble, velvety texture sometimes with smooth and silky nuances.
With its richness of expression, Pinot Gris sports a natural audacity, able to be matched with dishes usually for red wines. With its hint of earthy and smoky undergrowth, Pinot Gris d’Alsace makes an admirable match for pan-fried girolle mushrooms, risotto with boletus mushrooms.

instructions: Bring a 6-quart pot of highly salted water to boil over high heat. Add the shrimp to the boiling water and simmer until they are cooked through, 3 to 4 minutes. With a slotted spoon or strainer, transfer the shrimp to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking. Once cooled, drain, pat dry and reserve.                          Puree the creme fraiche, tarragon, scallions, zest and lemon juice in food processor until smooth. Season with salt and pepper. Transfer to a bowl and serve with the reserved shrimp.                          BYOC: For a little extra depth of flavor, try adding an anchovy fillet to the puree... trust me, it's great!

steps.step: Bring a 6-quart pot of highly salted water to boil over high heat.

Add the shrimp to the boiling water and simmer until they are cooked through, 3 to 4 minutes. With a slotted spoon or strainer, transfer the shrimp to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking. Once cooled, drain, pat dry and reserve.
Puree the creme fraiche, tarragon, scallions, zest and lemon juice in food processor until smooth. Season with salt and pepper.
Transfer to a bowl and serve with the reserved shrimp.
BYOC: For a little extra depth of flavor, try adding an anchovy fillet to the puree... trust me, it's great!
